description: Render dynamic HTML on the server using EJS, Pug, or Handlebars.

slides.title: Why Templates?
slides.content:
# Dynamic HTML üé®

Sometimes you want to serve HTML pages generated on the server (Server-Side Rendering).

Template engines allow you to inject data into HTML views before sending them to the client.

slides.title: Popular Engines
slides.content:
# Pick Your Flavor üç¶

- **EJS (Embedded JavaScript):** Uses plain HTML with `<% %>` tags. Simple.
- **Pug (formerly Jade):** Concise, whitespace-sensitive syntax. No closing tags.
- **Handlebars:** Logic-less templates. Mustache-style `{{ }}`.

slides.title: Setting up EJS
Using res.render()
EJS Syntax
slides.content:
# The Tags üè∑Ô∏è

- `<%= var %>`: Outputs the value (escaped HTML).
- `<%- var %>`: Outputs unescaped value (careful!).
- `<% code %>`: Executes JS logic (if statements, loops).
- `<%# comment %>`: Comments.

slides.title: Partials
slides.content:
# Reusing Components üß©

Include common headers or footers.

`views/header.ejs` contains `<nav>...</nav>`.

In `index.ejs`:
` <%- include('header'); %> `

Don't repeat yourself!

slides.title: Multiple Engines
slides.content:
# Mixing? üçπ

You can technically use multiple engines in one app by rendering with file extensions, but it's best practice to stick to one consistency.

slides.title: Engine Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Which template engine is known for using indentation and having no closing tags?

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Recap: Templates üìë

Separation of concerns.

- **Setup:** `app.set('view engine', ...)`
- **Render:** `res.render('view', data)`
- **EJS:** HTML + JS tags.
- **Partials:** Reusable snippets.
